001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A group of similar methods for getting hashes of points based on int coordinates in 2, 3, 4, or 6 dimensions and
005 * an int for state; the code is similar to {@link HastyPointHash} but will be much faster on GWT. This
006 * implementation has high enough quality to be useful as a source of random numbers based on positions, but would
007 * likely not be a good option in a hash table (or at least not as good as the tailored implementation of
008 * {@link Coord#hashCode()}; it is still better than {@link java.util.Objects#hash(Object...)}). Even on a desktop
009 * JVM, this class is faster than {@link PointHash} or {@link HastyPointHash}. The technique used here
010 * owes credit to Pelle Evensen for finding the significant quality increase from using multiple bitwise rotations XORed
011 * together, and Martin Roberts for discovering the connection between higher dimensional ranks and the appropriate
012 * numbers to gain similar qualities to adding the golden ratio mod 1 in 1D, using what had already been named
013 * "harmonious numbers." The only case where this can return different results on GWT than on a desktop or mobile
014 * JVM is when the inputs are GWT-specific out-of-range JS Numbers appearing to be ints, and that's a problem with
015 * the input rather than the algorithm.
016 * <br>
017 * Getting the bottom 24 bits of {@link #hashAll(int, int, int)}, dividing to get a float from 0 to 1, and graphing
018 * it produces <a href="https://i.imgur.com/vYWzVAR.png">this white-noise-like image</a>. The frequency magnitude of
019 * that image is <a href="https://i.imgur.com/6N39FPQ.png">this diagram</a>, which looks almost exactly like
020 * <a href="https://i.imgur.com/RSdUnSY.png">a diagram of the frequency magnitude of white noise</a>. This shows
021 * there are effectively no significant structural artifacts in the noise when interpreted as a float.
022 */
023public final class IntPointHash extends IPointHash.IntImpl {
024
025    @Override
026    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
027        return hashAll(x, y, state);
028    }
029
030    @Override
031    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
032        return hashAll(x, y, z, state);
033    }
034
035    @Override
036    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
037        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, state);
038    }
039
040    @Override
041    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
042        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, state);
043    }
044
045    @Override
046    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
047        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
048    }
049
050    /**
051     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
052     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
053     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
054     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
055     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
056     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
057     * @param x x position, as an int
058     * @param y y position, as an int
059     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
060     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
061     */
062    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int s) {
063        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
064        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
065    }
066    /**
067     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
068     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
069     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
070     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
071     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
072     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
073     * @param x x position, as an int
074     * @param y y position, as an int
075     * @param z z position, as an int
076     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
077     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
078     */
079    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
080        s ^= x * 0x1A36A9 ^ y * 0x157931 ^ z * 0x119725;
081        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
082    }
083
084    /**
085     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
086     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
087     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
088     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
089     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
090     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
091     * @param x x position, as an int
092     * @param y y position, as an int
093     * @param z z position, as an int
094     * @param w w position, as an int
095     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
096     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
097     */
098    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
099        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
100        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
101    }
102
103    /**
104     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
105     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
106     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
107     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
108     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
109     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
110     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
111     * @param x x position, as an int
112     * @param y y position, as an int
113     * @param z z position, as an int
114     * @param w w position, as an int
115     * @param u u position, as an int
116     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
117     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state s
118     */
119    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int s) {
120        s ^= x * 0x1C3360 ^ y * 0x18DA3A ^ z * 0x15E6DA ^ w * 0x134D28 ^ u * 0x110280;
121        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
122    }
123
124    /**
125     * A 32-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
126     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
127     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
128     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
129     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
130     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
131     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
132     * @param x x position, as an int
133     * @param y y position, as an int
134     * @param z z position, as an int
135     * @param w w position, as an int
136     * @param u u position, as an int
137     * @param v v position, as an int
138     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
139     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
140     */
141    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
142        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
143        return (s = (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493) ^ s >>> 11;
144    }
145
146    /**
147     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
148     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
149     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
150     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
151     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
152     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
153     * @param x x position, as an int
154     * @param y y position, as an int
155     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
156     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
157     */
158    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int s) {
159        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
160        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
161    }
162    /**
163     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
164     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
165     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
166     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
167     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
168     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
169     * @param x x position, as an int
170     * @param y y position, as an int
171     * @param z z position, as an int
172     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
173     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
174     */
175    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
176        s ^= x * 0x1A36A9 ^ y * 0x157931 ^ z * 0x119725;
177        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
178    }

180    /**
181     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
182     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
183     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
184     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
185     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
186     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
187     * @param x x position, as an int
188     * @param y y position, as an int
189     * @param z z position, as an int
190     * @param w w position, as an int
191     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
192     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
193     */
194    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
195        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
196        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
197    }

199    /**
200     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
201     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
202     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
203     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
204     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
205     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
206     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
207     * @param x x position, as an int
208     * @param y y position, as an int
209     * @param z z position, as an int
210     * @param w w position, as an int
211     * @param u u position, as an int
212     * @param v v position, as an int
213     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
214     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
215     */
216    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
217        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
218        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 24;
219    }

221    /**
222     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
223     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
224     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
225     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
226     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
227     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
228     * @param x x position, as an int
229     * @param y y position, as an int
230     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
231     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
232     */
233    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int s) {
234        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
235        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
236    }
237    /**
238     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
239     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
240     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
241     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
242     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
243     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
244     * @param x x position, as an int
245     * @param y y position, as an int
246     * @param z z position, as an int
247     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
248     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
249     */
250    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
251        s ^= x * 0x1A36A9 ^ y * 0x157931 ^ z * 0x119725;
252        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
253    }

255    /**
256     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
257     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
258     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
259     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
260     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
261     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
262     * @param x x position, as an int
263     * @param y y position, as an int
264     * @param z z position, as an int
265     * @param w w position, as an int
266     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
267     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
268     */
269    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
270        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
271        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
272    }

274    /**
275     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
276     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
277     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
278     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
279     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
280     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
281     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
282     * @param x x position, as an int
283     * @param y y position, as an int
284     * @param z z position, as an int
285     * @param w w position, as an int
286     * @param u u position, as an int
287     * @param v v position, as an int
288     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
289     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
290     */
291    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
292        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
293        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 26;
294    }
295    /**
296     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
297     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
298     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
299     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
300     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
301     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
302     * @param x x position, as an int
303     * @param y y position, as an int
304     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
305     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
306     */
307    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int s) {
308        s ^= x * 0x1827F5 ^ y * 0x123C21;
309        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;
310    }
311    /**
312     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
313     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
314     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
315     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
316     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
317     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.

322     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
323     */
324    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int s) {

326        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;

329    /**
330     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
331     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
332     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
333     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
334     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
335     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
336     * @param x x position, as an int
337     * @param y y position, as an int
338     * @param z z position, as an int
339     * @param w w position, as an int
340     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
341     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
342     */
343    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
344        s ^= x * 0x1B69E1 ^ y * 0x177C0B ^ z * 0x141E5D ^ w * 0x113C31;
345        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;
346    }

348    /**
349     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
350     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
351     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
352     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
353     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
354     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
355     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
356     * @param x x position, as an int
357     * @param y y position, as an int
358     * @param z z position, as an int
359     * @param w w position, as an int
360     * @param u u position, as an int
361     * @param v v position, as an int
362     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point 
363     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
364     */
365    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
366        s ^= x * 0x1CC1C5 ^ y * 0x19D7AF ^ z * 0x173935 ^ w * 0x14DEAF ^ u * 0x12C139 ^ v * 0x10DAA3;
367        return (s ^ (s << 19 | s >>> 13) ^ (s << 5 | s >>> 27) ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 >>> 27;
368    }
